definitions: work in an unskilled or experimental manner on mechanical repairs or adjustments
make small changes or improvements to something repeatedly without major alterations
examples: He loves to tinker with old radios in his garage
The mechanic tinkered with the engine for several hours
She keeps tinkering with the recipe until it tastes perfect
The programmer tinkered with the code throughout the weekend

definitions: apply a faint or delicate color to something using dye or paint
apply a thin film to car windows that reduces light transmission
examples: The hairdresser tinted her gray hair with auburn highlights
The artist tinted the background with soft pastel colors
They decided to tint their car windows for better privacy
The law prohibits tinting front windshields beyond certain levels

definitions: cause something to lean or fall over from an upright position
give someone money as a reward for service in addition to payment
give someone private or advance information about something potentially useful
examples: The strong wind tipped the garbage cans over last night
Be careful not to tip your chair back too far
She always tips the waiter twenty percent at restaurants
Don't forget to tip the delivery driver for good service
Someone tipped off the police about the planned robbery
He tipped me about the stock market opportunity yesterday

definitions: become physically or mentally exhausted from effort or strain
cause someone to feel fatigue or exhaustion through demands or activity
gradually lose interest or patience with something over time
examples: The hikers began to tire after climbing for six hours
She tires easily since recovering from her illness
The long lecture tired all the students in the classroom
Don't tire yourself out before the main event tonight
He quickly tired of playing the same video game daily
The audience tired of the speaker's repetitive arguments

definitions: give one tenth of annual income or produce to support religious organization
pay a tenth part of agricultural produce as tax in historical contexts
examples: Many church members tithe regularly to support their congregation
She decided to tithe her bonus to the local charity
Medieval farmers were required to tithe their harvest annually
The village had to tithe grain to the lord's estate

definitions: give a name or designation to a book, article, or artistic work
transfer legal ownership of property through formal documentation and registration
examples: She decided to title her novel after the main character
The artist titled the painting simply but meaningfully
They will title the property to the new owners tomorrow
The car was titled in both of their names jointly

definitions: cook or brown food by exposing it to radiant heat until crisp
raise glasses and drink in honor of someone or something ceremonially
warm oneself or something thoroughly near a heat source
examples: She likes to toast her bread until it's golden brown
The chef toasted the almonds before adding them to salad
Let's toast the bride and groom at their wedding reception
They toasted their success with champagne at the party
We toasted our feet by the fireplace after skiing
The cat loves to toast herself in the sunny window

definitions: ride downhill over snow or ice on a long flat sled
decline rapidly in value, amount, or quality like sliding downhill
examples: The children love to toboggan down the steep hill nearby
We tobogganed through the forest trail all afternoon yesterday
Stock prices tobogganed after the company announced poor earnings
His health tobogganed following the stressful divorce proceedings

definitions: touch, kick, or reach something with the front part of foot
conform to a rule or standard of behavior expected by authority
examples: The swimmer toed the starting line before the race began
She carefully toed the soccer ball into perfect position
All employees must toe the company line regarding dress code
The new senator refused to toe the party line completely

definitions: switch back and forth between two different states or options electronically
fasten something with a pin or bolt that passes through a loop
examples: Press this key to toggle between uppercase and lowercase letters
The button toggles the display between metric and imperial units
The sailor toggled the rope securely to the deck cleat
She toggled her coat closed against the cold wind

definitions: work extremely hard physically or mentally for long periods with great effort
move slowly and with difficulty through challenging conditions or terrain
examples: The farmers toiled in the fields from dawn until dusk
She toiled over her dissertation for three years straight
The climbers toiled up the steep mountain path slowly
We toiled through the deep snow for several hours

definitions: accept or endure someone or something unpleasant without interference or complaint
be capable of continued exposure to substance or conditions without adverse reaction
examples: She couldn't tolerate his rude behavior any longer at work
The manager won't tolerate lateness from any team members
Some patients cannot tolerate the side effects of chemotherapy
This plant tolerates drought conditions better than most species

definitions: ring a bell slowly and repeatedly especially for death or ceremony
have a gradual and cumulative harmful effect on someone or something
examples: The church bells tolled solemnly for the funeral service
They tolled the bell forty times for his age
Years of stress have tolled heavily on her health
The economic crisis tolled on small businesses particularly hard

definitions: strengthen and firm muscles through exercise to improve physical condition
modify the intensity or shade of colors in photography or printing
adjust the quality or character of musical or vocal sound production
examples: She tones her abs with daily planks and crunches
Swimming helps tone your entire body without joint stress
The photographer toned the image to create a vintage look
They toned down the bright colors for a subtler effect
The conductor asked the orchestra to tone down the volume
He carefully toned his voice to match the song's mood

definitions: touch or lick something with the tongue as animals or humans do
articulate notes or words precisely using tongue position in speech or music
examples: The cat tongued the milk from her bowl carefully
The baby tongued the new food suspiciously before swallowing
The flutist must tongue each note clearly for proper articulation
Students practice tonguing exercises to improve their pronunciation

definitions: work or shape something using hand tools or machine tools skillfully
drive a vehicle in a leisurely or casual manner without hurry
provide or equip a factory or workshop with necessary tools and equipment
examples: The craftsman carefully tooled the leather with intricate patterns
She tooled the metal piece to exact specifications
They tooled around town in their convertible all afternoon
We tooled along the coastal highway enjoying the scenery
The company tooled the new factory with state-of-the-art equipment
They need to tool up before starting mass production

definitions: make a short sharp sound with a horn or whistle
inhale cocaine or other drugs through the nose in informal usage
examples: The driver tooted his horn to warn the pedestrians
The train tooted as it approached the railroad crossing
He was caught tooting cocaine at the nightclub bathroom
Some celebrities tooted drugs during the wild party

definitions: exceed or surpass something in amount, degree, or achievement
reach the highest point or summit of a mountain or structure
cut off or remove the top part of something like plants
examples: Sales this quarter topped our previous record by twenty percent
Her performance topped all expectations at the competition
They finally topped the mountain after eight hours of climbing
The climbers topped the ridge just before sunset
The gardener topped the hedge to maintain its proper height
We need to top these carrots before storing them

definitions: fall forward or cause to fall forward from being unbalanced or unstable
remove someone from a position of authority or power especially suddenly
examples: The strong wind toppled several trees in the neighborhood
The toddler toppled over while learning to walk
The revolution toppled the dictator after thirty years of rule
Scandal toppled the CEO from his powerful position

definitions: deliberately set fire to something especially as arson or destruction
cut through metal using an oxyacetylene torch or similar tool
examples: Vandals torched three abandoned buildings last night downtown
The rioters threatened to torch the police station
The workers torched through the steel beams during demolition
He torched the old pipes to remove them quickly

definitions: cause severe physical or mental suffering to someone deliberately or through circumstances
annoy or provoke someone in a persistent and deliberate way
examples: Guilt tormented him for years after the accident happened
The disease tormented her with constant pain every day
The older children tormented the new student throughout the semester
Stop tormenting your sister with those scary stories

definitions: attack or sink a ship using self-propelled underwater explosive weapons
completely destroy or ruin a plan, project, or relationship deliberately
examples: The submarine torpedoed three enemy vessels during the battle
German U-boats torpedoed many merchant ships in wartime
His careless comments torpedoed the negotiations completely yesterday
The scandal torpedoed her chances of winning the election

definitions: deliberately inflict severe physical pain as punishment or to extract information
cause great mental suffering or anguish through actions or circumstances
examples: The regime tortured political prisoners to extract false confessions
They tortured him for hours trying to get information
The uncertainty tortured her throughout the long waiting period
Don't torture yourself with guilt over past mistakes

definitions: add up numbers or amounts to find the total sum
carry a small child or move while carrying young children
examples: She quickly totted up the bill at the restaurant
Let me tot these figures before submitting the report
She totted her baby around the shopping mall all afternoon
Parents were totting their toddlers to the playground

definitions: add up numbers or quantities to reach a complete sum
completely wreck or destroy something especially a vehicle in accident
reach a particular amount when all parts are added together
examples: Please total all the expenses from last month's receipts
The accountant totaled the quarterly earnings for the report
He totaled his new car just three days after buying it
The storm totaled several boats in the harbor
The damages totaled over fifty thousand dollars after assessment
Our donations totaled enough to fund the entire project

definitions: carry something by hand especially something heavy or cumbersome
transport goods or materials using a vehicle or container system
examples: She toted her heavy textbooks across campus every day
Workers toted boxes from the truck to the warehouse
The company totes fresh produce to markets throughout the region
They tote supplies to remote locations using helicopters

definitions: come into or be in physical contact with something using hands or body
affect someone emotionally creating feelings of sympathy or gratitude
deal with or mention a subject briefly without going into detail
examples: Please don't touch the artwork in the museum gallery
She gently touched his shoulder to get his attention
His kindness touched her heart during difficult times
The speech touched everyone in the audience deeply
The professor only touched on quantum physics briefly today
We barely touched the surface of this complex issue

definitions: travel to various places for pleasure, education, or inspection purposes
travel to different venues to give performances or appearances professionally
examples: They toured Europe for three weeks last summer vacation
The group will tour the factory before the meeting
The band tours internationally playing at major music festivals
The comedian tours college campuses throughout the academic year

definitions: participate in or organize a tournament or series of competitive contests
examples: Knights would tourney for honor and glory in medieval times
The chess players will tourney throughout the weekend event
Teams tourney every spring for the championship title
Professional gamers tourney for substantial prize money online

definitions: promote or praise something publicly especially to encourage sales or support
sell information about racehorses or give tips about betting outcomes
examples: The company heavily touts its environmental credentials in advertisements
Politicians tout their achievements during election campaigns constantly
He was caught touting false racing tips outside the track
Illegal operators tout insider information to desperate gamblers

definitions: pull something along behind using a rope, chain, or bar
pull a disabled vehicle or trailer behind another vehicle
examples: The boat towed the water skier across the lake smoothly
They had to tow the barge upstream against strong current
The truck towed our broken car to the repair shop
We tow our camping trailer to different sites each summer

definitions: dry or wipe something using an absorbent cloth after washing
give up or admit defeat in informal usage especially in boxing
examples: She toweled her hair dry after the morning shower
The swimmer toweled off quickly before the next race
After losing five games straight, he finally toweled it
The boxer's corner toweled when he couldn't continue fighting

definitions: rise to or reach a great height especially in comparison to surroundings
be markedly superior to others in quality, ability, or achievement
examples: The skyscraper towers over all other buildings downtown
Mountains tower above the valley floor majestically
She towers above her peers in mathematical ability
His achievements tower over those of his contemporaries

definitions: play with something without serious intent or purpose idly
consider an idea or possibility without serious intention to act
examples: The cat toyed with the mouse before catching it completely
She toyed with her food instead of eating properly
He's been toying with the idea of changing careers
Don't toy with her feelings if you're not serious

definitions: find or discover something by careful investigation or searching
copy a drawing or pattern by following lines through translucent paper
follow the course or trail of something through its development
examples: Police traced the stolen car to an abandoned warehouse
Historians traced her ancestry back three hundred years
The child traced the letters to practice writing skills
Artists often trace initial sketches before adding details
Scientists traced the virus transmission through the population
We traced the river from its source to the sea

definitions: follow footprints or other signs to find person or animal
monitor and record the progress or development of something systematically
record different instruments or voices on separate channels in music
examples: The hunter tracked the deer through fresh snow carefully
Dogs can track missing persons using scent trails
The system tracks employee productivity throughout each work shift
Parents track their children's academic progress using the app
The band tracked vocals separately from the instrumental parts
They tracked each instrument to allow better mixing later

definitions: buy and sell goods and services as a business activity
exchange one thing for another by mutual agreement without money
work in a skilled job especially involving manual or technical skills
examples: The company trades globally with partners in fifty countries
She trades stocks and bonds for major investment firms
Kids often trade baseball cards with their friends
Let's trade seats so you can see better
He trades as an electrician throughout the local area
She's traded as a plumber for fifteen years

definitions: legally register a symbol, word, or phrase representing a company or product
be a distinctive characteristic or feature that identifies someone or something
examples: The company trademarked their logo last year for protection
You should trademark your brand name before launching products
His sarcastic humor trademarked all his comedy performances
That particular guitar sound trademarked their music style

definitions: buy and sell illegal goods especially drugs or people
trade or deal in particular goods or commodities commercially
examples: The gang traffics drugs across the international border regularly
They were arrested for trafficking stolen artwork internationally
The company traffics in rare books and manuscripts
Merchants trafficked goods along the ancient silk road

definitions: walk or move slowly behind someone or something at a distance
drag or let something drag along the ground or behind while moving
follow tracks or signs to pursue person or animal
examples: The younger children trailed behind their parents through the museum
Our team trails by ten points in the fourth quarter
Her long dress trailed along the dusty floor elegantly
The boat trailed fishing lines in the water
The detective trailed the suspect for three days secretly
Wolves trail their prey for miles before attacking

definitions: teach a person or animal particular skills through practice and instruction
prepare physically for a sporting event through systematic exercise
point or aim a gun, camera, or light at a particular target
examples: She trains new employees in customer service protocols weekly
They trained their dog to perform amazing tricks
Athletes train for months before the Olympic games begin
He trains at the gym five days per week
The sniper trained his rifle on the distant target
Security cameras are trained on all entrance points

definitions: travel as a passenger on an electric rail vehicle in cities
transport goods or materials using a tramway system especially in mining
examples: We tram to work every morning through the city center
Tourists love to tram around San Francisco's historic districts
Miners trammed coal from deep underground to the surface
They tram ore through tunnels to the processing plant

definitions: walk with heavy steps making noise especially through difficult terrain
travel from place to place as a vagrant without permanent home
engage in casual sexual relationships with multiple partners disparagingly
examples: Soldiers tramped through the muddy fields all day long
We tramped for miles through deep snow yesterday
He tramped across the country during the Great Depression
Many workers tramped from town to town seeking employment
She was unfairly labeled for tramping around in her youth
The gossips accused her of tramping with various men

definitions: enter or put into a half-conscious state of altered awareness hypnotically
examples: The hypnotist tranced volunteers from the audience during the show
Some people trance easily during meditation sessions
The shaman tranced himself before the healing ceremony began
Rhythmic drumming can trance listeners into altered consciousness

definitions: conduct business dealings involving buying, selling, or exchanging goods and services
carry out or conduct negotiations or discussions to reach agreements
examples: The bank transacts millions of dollars in business daily
We transact all our business through secure online platforms
Diplomats transacted delicate negotiations throughout the peace talks
The lawyers transacted the merger details over several weeks

definitions: go beyond the normal limits or boundaries of something physical or conceptual
be or go beyond the range of human experience, reason, or belief
examples: Great art transcends cultural and temporal boundaries completely
Her talent transcends anything we've seen before
Some believe consciousness transcends physical death entirely
Meditation helps people transcend ordinary states of awareness

definitions: write down spoken words verbatim from audio recordings or dictation
copy written or printed text into another form or medium
arrange a piece of music for different instruments or voices
examples: The secretary transcribes all important meetings for company records
Court reporters transcribe testimony during legal proceedings accurately
Monks transcribed ancient manuscripts by hand for centuries
Students transcribe their messy notes into neat notebooks
The composer transcribed the orchestral piece for piano solo
Musicians often transcribe jazz solos to study improvisation

definitions: move from one place, person, or position to another location
legally convey ownership or rights from one person to another
move a design or pattern from one surface to another surface
examples: The company transferred him to their London office permanently
Students can transfer credits between accredited universities easily
They transferred the property deed to the new owners
She transferred her shares to her children last year
The artist transferred the design onto ceramic tiles carefully
You can transfer images onto fabric using special paper

definitions: make a complete or dramatic change in form, appearance, or character
change mathematical expression to different form maintaining equivalence
change the voltage of electrical current using a transformer
examples: The renovation completely transformed the old building into luxury apartments
Exercise and diet transformed his health within six months
Students learn to transform equations in advanced algebra class
The software transforms data into visual representations instantly
The device transforms high voltage to usable household current
Power stations transform electricity before distribution to homes

definitions: pass through or across an area while traveling to destination
pass across the face of a celestial body or meridian astronomically
examples: Thousands of commuters transit through this station every morning
Ships transit the canal to save thousands of miles
Venus will transit the sun next Tuesday afternoon visibly
The satellite transits overhead four times each day
